message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Adaptive backstepping control for a class of nonlinear systems with output modeling error and external disturbance
Paper Abstract: In this paper, a new robust adaptive control scheme is proposed for a class of nonlinear systems with external disturbance and output modeling error. The output modeling error considered here is allowed to depend on all systems states. Thus, traditional backstepping techniques cannot be used in the controller design due to such an unknown output modeling error existing in coordinate changes. This problem has been solved by the developed robust adaptive control scheme. By establishing the upper bound function of the unknown output modeling error depending on all the system states, the linear inequality relationship between the state vector and the transformation vector is obtained. This is the key to stability analysis. Input saturation is also considered in the controller design. It is shown that the proposed adaptive control scheme can ensure that all signals in the closed-loop system are bounded. Simulation studies verify the effectiveness of the proposed scheme.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed the web search for "nonlinear systems." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Basics

A nonlinear system is defined as any system that is not linear, that is any system that does not satisfy the superposition principle. More simply, a nonlinear system is any problem where the variable(s) to solve for cannot be written as a linear sum of independent components.

## Key Characteristics

Nonlinear systems do not follow the principle of superposition (linearity and homogeneity), may have multiple isolated equilibrium points, and may exhibit properties such as limit cycle, bifurcation, and chaos. Additionally, solutions of nonlinear systems may not exist for all times.

## Mathematical Analysis

Problems involving nonlinear differential equations are extremely diverse, and methods of solution or analysis are problem dependent.(no content)One of the greatest difficulties of nonlinear problems is that it is not generally possible to combine known solutions into new solutions, whereas in linear problems, a family of linearly independent solutions can be used to construct general solutions through the superposition principle.

## Applications

Examples of nonlinear differential equations are the Navier–Stokes equations in fluid dynamics and the Lotka–Volterra equations in biology.(no content)All real control systems are nonlinear.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "robust control"

Links: [{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_methods_in_control_theory"},{"title":"Nichols plot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nichols_plot"},{"title":"Minor loop feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minor_loop_feedback"},{"title":"Keith Glover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keith_Glover"},{"title":"Power to the edge - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_to_the_edge_(management_technique)"},{"title":"Youla–Kucera parametrization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youla–Kucera_parametrization"},{"title":"Innovative Vector Control Consortium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innovative_Vector_Control_Consortium"}]

Here's what I found about robust control:

## Definition

Robust control refers to theory of feedback regulation that began taking shape in the late 1970's and onwards, where modeling uncertainty is explicitly acknowledged, modeled, and taken into account in control design.

## Key Concepts

Tolerance to modeling uncertainty is an essential part of any feedback control scheme, and the ability of a feedback control system to maintain stability and performance under uncertainty is referred to as robustness.(no content)A controller designed for a particular set of model parameters is said to be robust if it also works well for values of the parameters near the nominal.

## Historical Development

The term robust control was not used until the 1980's when modern methods started being developed to optimize for parametric and non-parametric modeling uncertainty, and the theory took shape in the 1980s and 1990s, and is still active today.

## Important Methods

H-infinity methods are used in control theory to synthesize controllers to achieve stabilization with guaranteed performance, where a control designer expresses the control problem as a mathematical optimization problem and then finds the controller that solves this optimization.(no content)Robust control guarantees that if changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "adaptive backstepping control"

Links: [{"title":"Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstepping"},{"title":"Petar V. Kokotovic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petar_V._Kokotovic"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Strict-feedback form - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strict-feedback_form"},{"title":"Talk:Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Backstepping"},{"title":"Adaptive step size - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_step_size"},{"title":"Backpropagation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Back_propagation"},{"title":"Active disturbance rejection control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_disturbance_rejection_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about adaptive backstepping control:

## Overview

Backstepping is a technique developed circa 1990 by Petar V. Kokotovic and others for designing stabilizing controls for a special class of nonlinear dynamical systems.(no content)Kokotovic made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control especially the backstepping stabilization method.

## How It Works

Systems are built from subsystems that radiate out from an irreducible subsystem that can be stabilized using some other method. Because of this recursive structure, the designer can start the design process at the known-stable system and "back out" new controllers that progressively stabilize each outer subsystem.(no content)Systems in strict-feedback form are stabilized by stabilizing the smallest cascaded system and then backstepping to the next cascaded system and repeating the procedure.

## Integration with Adaptive Control

Any system in the special many-integrator strict-feedback form can be feedback stabilized using a straightforward procedure that can even be automated (e.g., as part of an adaptive control algorithm). This indicates that backstepping can be integrated with adaptive control techniques to handle systems with uncertain or time-varying parameters.

## Applications

Feedback linearization, backstepping, and sliding mode control are nonlinear control methods that normally take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about adaptive backstepping control:

## Overview

Backstepping is a technique developed circa 1990 by Petar V. Kokotovic and others for designing stabilizing controls for a special class of nonlinear dynamical systems.(no content)Kokotovic made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control especially the backstepping stabilization method.

## How It Works

Systems are built from subsystems that radiate out from an irreducible subsystem that can be stabilized using some other method. Because of this recursive structure, the designer can start the design process at the known-stable system and "back out" new controllers that progressively stabilize each outer subsystem.(no content)Systems in strict-feedback form are stabilized by stabilizing the smallest cascaded system and then backstepping to the next cascaded system and repeating the procedure.

## Integration with Adaptive Control

Any system in the special many-integrator strict-feedback form can be feedback stabilized using a straightforward procedure that can even be automated (e.g., as part of an adaptive control algorithm). This indicates that backstepping can be integrated with adaptive control techniques to handle systems with uncertain or time-varying parameters.

## Applications

Feedback linearization, backstepping, and sliding mode control are nonlinear control methods that normally take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.

Here's an overview of feedback control systems based on the search results:

## Definition

A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.(no content)Its name comes from the information path in the system: process inputs have an effect on the process outputs, which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.

## How It Works

The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.(no content)In the case of linear feedback systems, a control loop including sensors, control algorithms, and actuators is arranged in an attempt to regulate a variable at a setpoint.

## Real-World Example

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

## Advantages Over Open-Loop Systems

Control systems that include some sensing of the results they are trying to achieve are making use of feedback and can adapt to varying circumstances to some extent.(no content)Closed-loop controllers have the following advantages over open-loop controllers: disturbance rejection and guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties.

I've performed a web search on stability analysis in control theory. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

In control theory, and especially stability theory, a stability criterion establishes when a system is stable.

## Key Methods and Tools

Graphical systems like the root locus, Bode plots or the Nyquist plots are commonly used for analyzing system stability. Root locus analysis is a graphical method for examining how the roots of a linear time-invariant (LTI) system change with variation of a certain system parameter, commonly a gain within a feedback system.

## Lyapunov Stability

The stability of a general dynamical system with no input can be described with Lyapunov stability criteria.(no content)A. M. Lyapunov was a pioneer in successful endeavors to develop a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.

## For Nonlinear Systems

Techniques for analyzing nonlinear systems include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.(no content)There are generalizations of the Nyquist criterion for non-linear systems, such as the circle criterion and the scaled relative graph of a nonlinear operator. Additionally, other stability criteria like Lyapunov methods can also be applied for non-linear systems.

## Important Concepts

Controllability and observability are main issues in the analysis of a system before deciding the best control strategy to be applied, or whether it is even possible to control or stabilize the system.

Links: [{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"},{"title":"Control loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_loop"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Phase margin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_margin"},{"title":"Sensitivity (control systems) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensitivity_(control_systems)"},{"title":"Closed system (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_system_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Loop gain","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loop_gain"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"},{"title":"Negative feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_feedback"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about closed-loop control systems:

## Definition and Basics

A closed-loop controller or feedback controller is a control loop which incorporates feedback, in contrast to an open-loop controller or non-feedback controller.(no content)A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

## How It Works

The system's name comes from the information path: process inputs (e.g., voltage applied to an electric motor) have an effect on the process outputs (e.g., speed or torque of the motor), which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result (the control signal) is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.(no content)A control loop consists of the process sensor, the controller function, and the final control element (FCE) which controls the process necessary to automatically adjust the value of a measured process variable (PV) to equal the value of a desired set-point (SP).

## Real-World Example

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

## Advantages

Closed-loop controllers have advantages over open-loop controllers including disturbance rejection (such as hills in the cruise control example) and guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties.

## Key Controllers

A proportional–integral–derivative controller (PID controller) is a control loop feedback mechanism control technique widely used in control systems.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about closed-loop control systems:

## Definition and Basics

A closed-loop controller or feedback controller is a control loop which incorporates feedback, in contrast to an open-loop controller or non-feedback controller.(no content)A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

## How It Works

The system's name comes from the information path: process inputs (e.g., voltage applied to an electric motor) have an effect on the process outputs (e.g., speed or torque of the motor), which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result (the control signal) is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.(no content)A control loop consists of the process sensor, the controller function, and the final control element (FCE) which controls the process necessary to automatically adjust the value of a measured process variable (PV) to equal the value of a desired set-point (SP).

## Real-World Example

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

## Advantages

Closed-loop controllers have advantages over open-loop controllers including disturbance rejection (such as hills in the cruise control example) and guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties.

## Key Controllers

A proportional–integral–derivative controller (PID controller) is a control loop feedback mechanism control technique widely used in control systems.

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Adaptive cruise control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_cruise_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Self-tuning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-tuning"},{"title":"Adaptive traffic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_traffic_control"},{"title":"Continuous monitoring and adaptive control (stormwater management) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_monitoring_and_adaptive_control_(stormwater_management)"},{"title":"Xbox Adaptive Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Adaptive_Controller#:~:text=The co-creator of the,much they could be ..."},{"title":"Real-time adaptive security - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_adaptive_security"},{"title":"File:Xbox Adaptive Controller V&A.JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Xbox_Adaptive_Controller_V&A.JPG"},{"title":"Adaptive autonomy","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_autonomy"}]

Here are the search results for "adaptive control":

## General Overview

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## Key Differences

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Foundations and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification.(no content)Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

## Types of Adaptive Control

Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters.

## Applications

A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control. This body of work has focused on guaranteeing stability of a model reference adaptive control scheme using Lyapunov arguments.

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"}]

Here are the search results for **Lyapunov stability**:

## Overview

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.

## Basic Concepts

Near a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable, the system remains stable under small disturbances. More specifically, Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium remain close enough, while asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

## Lyapunov Functions

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Historical Development

A. M. Lyapunov was a pioneer in successful endeavors to develop a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.(no content)The interest in it suddenly skyrocketed during the Cold War period when the so-called "Second Method of Lyapunov" was found to be applicable to the stability of aerospace guidance systems.

## Applications

The theory has diverse applications across several fields. ISS unified the Lyapunov and input-output stability theories and revolutionized our view on stabilization of nonlinear systems, design of robust nonlinear observers, stability of nonlinear interconnected control systems, nonlinear detectability theory, and supervisory adaptive control.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

todos.content: For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

todos.content: Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
todos.activeForm: Editing triples_output.json with all triple information

todos.content: Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py
todos.activeForm: Running validation script

todos.content: If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the paper analysis. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** **Contribution** - The paper proposes a new robust adaptive control scheme for nonlinear systems.

**Key Technologies and Methodologies Identified:**

1. **Backstepping** (Method - Proposes) - Core control methodology for the adaptive scheme
2. **Nonlinear system** (Task - Uses) - The problem domain being addressed
3. **Adaptive control** (Method - Proposes) - Control law that adjusts to varying system parameters
4. **Robust control** (Method - Proposes) - Designed to handle modeling uncertainties and disturbances
5. **Lyapunov stability** (Method - Uses) - Used for stability analysis and establishing bounds on output modeling error
6. **Closed-loop controller** (Concept - Uses) - Ensures all signals in the control system remain bounded

**Validation Status:** ✅ All checks passed successfully

The paper contains 6 triples (4 methods, 1 task, 1 concept) that capture the essential technologies and methodologies it uses and proposes. The analysis has been saved to `triples_output.json` with proper Wikipedia references for each entity.

Sources:
- [Backstepping](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstepping)
- [Nonlinear system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system)
- [Adaptive control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control)
- [Robust control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control)
- [Lyapunov stability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability)
- [Closed-loop controller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller)
